translated: Jātaka Stories
Twenty-second Section
The Chapter with Mātaṅga🔽The Shorter “Wild Goose” Birth Story
“These geese are flying away,
their wings trembling in fear.
Their feathers are green and their color is golden,
so, Sumukha, fly away if you like.
Abandoning me, a relative,
who is alone and in a trap,
they are going without a care—
why do you fly away alone?
Fly away, best of fliers,
there is no friendship with one who is caught.
Don’t be destroyed for the sake of one who is fearless,

analyzed: kāmam su mukha pakkama  na aham dukkha pareto ti
translated: so, Sumukha, fly away if you like.”🔽“I’m not abandoning you, Dhataraṭṭha,
because you’re in a difficult situation.
Whether I live or die,
it will be with you.”
“This is noble and good,
what you say, Sumukha.
But I was testing you,
so I said, ‘Fly away.’”
“He goes from foot to foot,
the god who moves in the sky.
You don’t understand the trap and the snare,
you supreme one among geese.”
“When defeat comes,
when one’s life is coming to an end,
then one doesn’t understand the net and the snare,
even when one is caught in them.”
“These geese are flying away,
the cranes are flying away in fear;
The golden-hued one with the yellow feathers,
you alone are left behind.

original: Ete bhutvā ca pitvā ca,🔽pakkamanti vihaṅgamā;
analyzed: ete bhutvā ca pitvā ca  pakkamanti vihaṅgamā
translated: These birds, having eaten and drunk,🔽are flying away;
The cranes are flying away without concern,
you alone are left behind.
What is this? Are you a god?
You are left behind, caring for the bound one.
The birds have left him behind,
why are you alone left behind?”
“He is my friend, my god,
my friend, dear as life to me;
I will not abandon him,

original: yāva kālassa pariyāyaṁ”.🔽“Yo ca tvaṁ sakhino hetu,
analyzed: yāva kālassa pariyāya  yaḥ ca tvam sakhinaḥ
translated: until the time has passed.”🔽“Since you are willing to give up your life
for the sake of your friend,
I will release your friend,
let the king be your follower.”
“Be happy, hunter,
together with all your relatives;
Just as I am happy today,
seeing the king of the birds released.”
“I hope you are well,
I hope you are healthy;
I hope this country is prosperous,
that you rule righteously.”🔽“I am well, O goose,

analyzed: kusalam ca iva me hasa 🔽atho hasa anāmaya
translated: and I am healthy,
And this kingdom is prosperous,
through the Dhamma, with human beings.”
“I hope you have no quarrel
with any of your ministers;
I hope your enemies are defeated,
like the shadow by the sun’s rays.”
“I have no quarrel
with any of my ministers;
and my enemies are defeated,
like the shadow by the sun’s rays.”
“I hope you have a wife who is your equal,
obedient, and pleasant to look at;
endowed with beauty, wealth, and family,
who follows your wishes.”
“I have a wife who is my equal,
obedient, and pleasant to look at;
endowed with beauty, wealth, and family,
who follows my wishes.”
“I hope you have many sons,
well-born, increasing the kingdom;
endowed with wisdom and energy,
rejoicing in every way.”
“I have a thousand sons,
Dhataraṭṭha, born of me;
Tell me what they should do,
they will not disobey your words.”
“Even if he is well-born,
by birth or by training,
if he later makes an effort,
he sinks in difficulty and hardship.
For one of limited wisdom,
a great opening appears.
Just as at night one sees forms,
large ones in particular.
One who is unwise in the unessential,
does not find wisdom at all;
Like a deer in a mountain fastness,

analyzed: antarāya iva sīdati  hīna ja c ca upi ce
translated: he sinks down in the middle.🔽Even if one is born in a low family,
if a man is energetic and wise,
endowed with good conduct and virtue,
he shines like a fire.

original: Etaṁ me upamaṁ katvā,🔽putte vijjāsu vācaya;
analyzed: etam me upamam katvā  putte vijjāsu vācaya
translated: Having made this simile for me,🔽educate your sons in the sciences;
when they are grown, the wise one,
like rain on a well-ploughed field.”
The Short Goose Jātaka is the sixth.
